body: Thanks, @deadwind4!

@namrathamyske, when a ref doesn't have a max snapshot age, the branch will use the `expireOlderThan` timestamp. That timestamp is set so that the snapshot would be aged off, except that it is referenced by the branch with effectively infinite snapshot age. We could set something smaller, but since the point is to make the branch protect that snapshot, using the highest possible age seems fine.

Thanks, @stevenzwu!

I know we still need to discuss the builder that makes reading as RowData easy, but I went ahead and merged this because we can add that later.

No problem.  Actually I do think this change is still valid, as it's Iceberg API and it's better to protect the caller, if you want to proceed.

I made another issue about what we are talking about: https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/5132, maybe we can fix it in the filter pushdown part by not pushing down the complex predicates.

Thanks @rdblue!

I have a branch that will update all of the tests to use this. Let me push that and open it as well =)
cc @rdblue as this PR can replace https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/5133

I have a PR, https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/5135, that can replace this PR and also updates the base class `RequestResponseTestBase`, to always check the serialized fields.

RIght now, the base class is testing that the java object has the correctly named fields. It's just by chance that the names match up with the spec. Now it's enforced with https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/5135 cc @rdblue @danielcweeks
I am also +1 on a Rust SDK.
@rdblue, Could you please take another look?

@klam-shop @zoucao This is the PR for source builder that puts everything together. You can try the MVP version out from the master branch. Also your feedbacks on the source builder/construction are welcomed.

> 

Thanks for your great work, @stevenzwu, and we will try it as soon as possible.

I think it would make sense to consider for example FoundationDB as storage layer for the metadata.
That's what Snowflake and Firebolt currently use.
Delta seems to also consider this (https://github.com/delta-io/delta/issues/867).
Of course it can be a another similar transactional, highly-available, scalable and low latency store (if it exists). Decoupling the metadata from the actual storage would open a lot of possible new use cases. In particular evolving Iceberg to the storage layer for "modern cloud datawarehouses".
https://doris.apache.org/docs/ecosystem/external-table/iceberg-of-doris.html

> > > @eric666666 改了下确实可以，local模式不会阻塞了。另外有个问题请教下，我在合并小文件时，对于分区表老是有些等值删除文件没有清理掉，导致小文件很多。如果对表做一次比较重的数据文件重写（比如设定的条件能覆盖到所有分区的所有数据文件）有可能就清理掉了，但这么做代价太高了。难道也是local模式下才会这样？on yarn或on k8s能正常清理掉？
> > 
> > 
> > 我们可以加下好友交流下，eq-delete file和pos-delete file，重写后，过期快照不删除的问题，我一直再尝试修，目前还没有能解决
> 
> 好啊，qq：4612815 我想我已经找到原因了，qq上详聊

我测了下 [https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3990](url)，貌似能解决分区表快照过期，删除文件未清理掉的问题

You are right. We shouldn't push down the complex predicate filters. I think we should catch the IllegalArgumentException [here](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/spark/v3.2/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/source/SparkScanBuilder.java#L99) and then the complex predicate filter won't be pushed. Similar as [this behavior](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/master/spark/v3.2/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/spark/source/SparkScanBuilder.java#L106).

I will open a PR to fix this.

> 

我加你啦，之前我排查了好像和delete file的manifest在重写和快照过期的时候，sequence number小于最新分区data file的sequence number也没有去删除，这个PR我也看了，有个大佬说这个PR改动比较大，你这边patch后有持续跑一段时间吗？

  execute("CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS  flink_iceberg_table ( " +
                "       id                  BIGINT                          ," +
                "       data                STRING                           " +
                ") WITH ( " +
                "       'connector' = 'iceberg'                             ," +
                "       'catalog-name' = 'iceberg'                          ," +
                "       'catalog-type' = 'hive'                             ," +
                "       'catalog-database' = 'flink_demo'                   ," +
                "       'catalog-table' = 'iceberg_table'                   ," +
                "       'uri' = 'thrift://192.168.90.150:9083'              ," +
                "       'engine.hive.enabled' = 'true'                      ," +
                "       'warehouse' = '" + WAREHOUSE + "'                    " +
                ")"
        );

Hey @jun-he [I'm using singledispatch over singledispatchmethod]:
https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/2f550cd65cfb2c7db689774dfee5fba70099de28/python/src/iceberg/avro/reader.py#L250-L317

For the same reason as you mentioned (performance). Using singledispatch also allows you to set the types in the function signature, which is nice for static analysis. Maybe another reason to go for singledispatch over singledispatchmethod? :)
Thanks for reviewing, @kbendick and @danielcweeks!
@kbendick, can you please update this since #5133 was merged and the other fields need to be corrected?
Thanks @hmit for discovering the issue and providing a fix. Thanks @kbendick for review. Thanks @szehon-ho for review and merge!

Actually I had a thought of an optimization, I think for struct column predicate we can pushdown to the nested columns like:

where col= struct{10, 'data'} => col.a = 10 and col.b='data'

It does get a bit trickier with collections (can be IN?)

So the open-ended question is 1) whether we should do it 2) whether Iceberg should do it or Spark should do it generically.  Open to thoughts on this, and doing it as a second phase if we do it.  @sunchao mentioned it may be done today with spark-parquet tables?

Since this is the first commit of a table, you could potentially get the create table DDL from spark `SHOW CREATE TABLE` and then do some variant of `REPLACE TABLE <tbl>`.

Sort of a hack, but might be a worthwhile avenue of investigation.
Let me take another look as well.

@szehon-ho, the REST catalog can support `registerTable`. It still uses metadata locations, it just allows the server to cache metadata and send it so the client doesn't need to read it.

Do we also want to deprecate `CombinedScanTask` so we can just use the group after 1.0?

I haven't made my mind on deprecating `CombinedScanTask` cause it is so widely used...
We will also have to break `TableScan` if we switch to `ScanTaskGroup`.

Restarting as Flink test is somehow cancelled.

There's a failing bloom filter related test in Java CI
```
org.apache.iceberg.parquet.TestBloomRowGroupFilter > testBytesEq FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: Should not read: cannot match a new generated binary
        at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:89)
        at org.junit.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:42)
        at org.junit.Assert.assertFalse(Assert.java:65)
        at org.apache.iceberg.parquet.TestBloomRowGroupFilter.testBytesEq(TestBloomRowGroupFilter.java:587)
```

Rerunning to see if it's just flaky.

@rdblue The issue I mentioned is only critical with blocking queue. Because the producer thread can block forever and if the pool is full of such threads, no new tasks can be run. If we have reached consensus to use blocking queue, I can submit a PR for it.
Sure, @rdblue. I have updated https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/5044.

> Did you see this in practice with a corrupt file?

I haven't.
Iceberg library doesn't write such invalid content.

i also don't see currently that this could be exploited for security reasons

> what problem is this fixing?

we incorrectly accept an incorrect input which ought to be rejected

Thanks for the reviews!

I'm running into the same issue running the `rewrite_manifests` procedure on a table (created via batch). Retries fail with the same error consistently. @igorcalabria did you ever find a solution/configuration change besides retries?
@amogh-jahagirdar Took a pull from your PR. let me know if my commit https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/5150/commits/8132d205f895208f36344dcc8dcc2794052146ab looks good.

For the record, I was able to resolve this by (much in line with @otayel's suggestion):
1. Reducing the number of spark executors (to 1, in my case)
2. configuring the aws sdk s3 stream buffer size:
```
spark.driver.extraJavaOptions -Dcom.amazonaws.sdk.s3.defaultStreamBufferSize=512m
spark.executor.extraJavaOptions -Dcom.amazonaws.sdk.s3.defaultStreamBufferSize=512m
```
@rajarshisarkar, can you fix 3.3 as well?
There's a few small changes I can make so that more Spark workflows will terminate early if one fails, but that won't necessarily resolve the problem entirely by any means.
Thanks for the reviews! Here's the follow-up PR: https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/5154

> We will also have to break TableScan if we switch to ScanTaskGroup.

Yes we should add this to 3.3 also.
